long_desc.thetext:
This is a tracking bug for Change: Django18
For more details, see: https://fedoraproject.org//wiki/Changes/Django18

Update python-django to version 1.8.
*** Bug 1191075 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

This message is a reminder that Fedora 22 Change Checkpoint: Completion deadline (testable) is on 2015-02-24 [1].

At this point, all accepted Changes should be substantially complete, and testable. Additionally, if a change is to be enabled by default, it must be so enabled at Change Completion deadline.

This bug should be set at least to the MODIFIED state to indicate that it achieved completeness. Status will be provided to FESCo right after the deadline. If, for any reasons, your Change is not in required state, let me know and we will try to find solution. Fedora 22 is going to be strictly time based release. For Changes you decide to cancel/move to the next release, please use the NEW status and set needinfo on me and it will be acted upon. 

In case of any questions, don't hesitate to ask Wrangler (jreznik). Thank you.

[1] https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Releases/22/Schedule

Django project still has Django-1.8 alpha 1. It was released Jan 17th.

Currently 1 single release blocker bug:
https://code.djangoproject.com/query?status=assigned&status=new&version=master&severity=Release+blocker

After discussing this on irc, I will push the latest alpha to rawhide on Feb. 25th. 

If possible, I'll do the same for f22 branch.

If the following is true, I'd wait for the beta instead of pushing an alpha version.
-----------------

Subject: 	Re: status of 1.8 release blockers
Date: 	Tue, 24 Feb 2015 17:08:39 -0800 (PST)
From: 	Tim Graham <timograham@gmail.com>
Reply-To: 	django-developers@googlegroups.com
To: 	django-developers@googlegroups.com



Zero blockers as of this writing. If we survive the next 12 hours with
no new ones, I'll release the beta around then (famous last words).
Just built python-django-1.8-0.5.b1.fc23 in rawhide.

Proposed as a Freeze Exception for 22-alpha by Fedora user mrunge using the blocker tracking app because:

 Django-1.8 beta was released 1 day after alpha freeze.
It's now included in rawhide and should be allowed to be pushed to f22.
It is NOT build for f22

* should fix your issue,
* was pushed to the Fedora 22 testing repository,
* should be available at your local mirror within two days.
Update it with:
# su -c 'yum update --enablerepo=updates-testing python-django-1.8-0.5.b1.fc22'
as soon as you are able to.
Please go to the following url:
https://admin.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2015-2756/python-django-1.8-0.5.b1.fc22
then log in and leave karma (feedback).

Discussed at today's blocker review meeting [1].

This bug was rejected as Freeze Exception - This package doesn't come included on any release media and can be fixed with an update at a later date. No need for FE status.

http://meetbot.fedoraproject.org/fedora-blocker-review/2015-03-02/

I've written some stuff at https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Documentation_Development_Web_Beat#Django_1.8 to cover this change. Matthias, feel free to edit or ping me if you see room for change or improvement.
python-django-1.8-0.5.b1.fc22 has been pushed to the Fedora 22 stable repository.  If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

> https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Documentation_Development_Web_Beat#Django_1.8
> to cover this change. Matthias, feel free to edit or ping me if you see room
> for change or improvement.

Thank you Pete, very much appreciated!

bugs.title: CVE-2015-2316 python-django: Django: possible denial of service in strip_tags() [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2015-2316 python-django: Django: possible denial of service in strip_tags() [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2015-2316 Django: possible denial of service in strip_tags()

long_desc.thetext:
The following flaw was found in Django:

In a previous release, django.utils.html.strip_tags was changed to work iteratively. The problem is that the size of the input it is processing can increase on each iteration which results in an infinite loop in strip_tags(). This issue only affects versions of Python that haven't received a bugfix in HTMLParser (http://bugs.python.org/issue20288); namely Python < 2.7.7 and 3.3.5. Some operating system vendors have also backported the fix for the Python bug into their packages of earlier versions.

To remedy this issue, strip_tags() will now return the original input if it detects the length of the string it is processing increases. Remember that absolutely NO guarantee is provided about the results of strip_tags() being HTML safe. So NEVER mark safe the result of a strip_tags() call without escaping it first, for example with django.utils.html.escape.

This issue affects Django versions 1.8.x, 1.7.x, and 1.6.x. This issue is fixed in versions 1.8 release candidate 1 (or beta 3), 1.7.7, and 1.6.11.

Acknowledgements:

Red Hat would like to thank the upstream Django project for reporting this issue.

Created attachment 1002792
is-safe-url-master.diff

Created attachment 1002793
strip-tags-1.8.diff

Created attachment 1002794
strip-tags-1.7.diff

Created attachment 1002795
strip-tags-1.6.diff

Created attachment 1002796
strip-tags-master.diff

External References:

https://www.djangoproject.com/weblog/2015/mar/18/security-releases/

bugs.title: CVE-2015-2317 python-django: Django: possible XSS attack via user-supplied redirect URLs [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2015-2317 python-django: Django: possible XSS attack via user-supplied redirect URLs [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2015-2317 Django: possible XSS attack via user-supplied redirect URLs

long_desc.thetext:
The following flaw was found in Django:

Django relies on user input in some cases (e.g. django.contrib.auth.views.login and i18n) to redirect the user to an "on success" URL. The security checks for these redirects (namely django.utils.http.is_safe_url()) accepted URLs with leading control characters and so considered URLs like \x08javascript:... safe. This issue doesn't affect Django currently, since we only put this URL into the Location response header and browsers seem to ignore JavaScript there. Browsers we tested also treat URLs prefixed with control characters such as %08//example.com as relative paths so redirection to an unsafe target isn't a problem either.

However, if a developer relies on is_safe_url() to provide safe redirect targets and puts such a URL into a link, they could suffer from an XSS attack as some browsers such as Google Chrome ignore control characters at the start of a URL in an anchor href.

This issue affects Django versions 1.8.x, 1.7.x, 1.6.x, and 1.4.x. This issue is fixed in versions 1.8 release candidate 1 (or beta 3), 1.7.7, 1.6.11, and 1.4.20.

Acknowledgements:

Red Hat would like to thank the upstream Django project for reporting this issue.

Created attachment 1002809
is-safe-url-1.4.diff

Created attachment 1002810
is-safe-url-1.6.diff

Created attachment 1002811
is-safe-url-1.7.diff

Created attachment 1002812
is-safe-url-1.8.diff

Created attachment 1002813
is-safe-url-master.diff

External References:

https://www.djangoproject.com/weblog/2015/mar/18/security-releases/
